questions.text: All of the following are included among the major criteria of the modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, except:

choices.text: Echocardiography showing endocardial involvement with definite vegetations
Coxiella burnetii anti-phase I IgG antibody titer greater than 1:800
At least two consecutive positive blood cultures for Coxiella burnetii

questions.solution:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is one of the major criteria of modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. All other options are true.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetations.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of:

  • Two major criteria or
  • One major and three minor criteria or
  • Five minor criteria

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Clinical criteria
  2. Pathologic criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

Presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Clinical Criteria

Major Criteria

1. Positive blood culture

Typical microorganism for IE from 2 separate blood cultures.

(or)

Persistently positive blood culture of an organism consistent with IE from:

  • Blood cultures drawn >12 h apart.
  • All of 3 or a majority of ≥4 separate blood cultures, with first and last drawn at least 1 h apart.

(or)

Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti or phase I IgG antibody titer of >1:800.

 

2. Evidence of endocardial involvement

Echocardiographic identification of oscillating intracardiac mass on valve or implant or in the path of regurgitant jets

(or)

New Valvular regurgitation

Minor Criteria

1. Predisposing heart lesion or intravenous drug use

2. Fever ≥38.0°C (≥100.4°F)

3. Vascular lesions: Major arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions.

4. Immunological evidence: Glomerulonephritis, Osler nodes, Roth spots, rheumatoid factor.

5. Microbiologic evidence: Positive blood culture but not meeting the major criterion, or serologic evidence of active infection with an organism consistent with infective endocarditis.

 

Pathological Criteria

1. Microorganisms demonstrated by culture or histologic examination, in vegetation, embolus from vegetation, or intracardiac abscess

(or)

2. Histologic confirmation of active endocarditis in vegetation or intracardiac abscess

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established, if symptoms resolve and do not recur with ≤4 days of antibiotic therapy, or if surgery or autopsy after ≤4 days of antimicrobial therapy yields no histologic evidence of endocarditis.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the General Surgery Department of a Hospital. You have been given the task of arranging the following surgeries to be posted for tomorrow’s Operation Theatre. Which of the following surgeries will you post first in the OT list
questions.solution:
Right hemithyroidectomy is a Clean Procedure and hence shall occupy the first position in the given list of surgeries.

Cleaner surgeries are posted first in the OT list.

Clean Procedures

  • CABG, Thyroid Sx, Breast Sx ( except abscess), Knee Replacement

Clean contaminated 

  • Gastrointestinal or genitourinary system without inflammation 
  • Eg: Elective appendicectomy, Elective cholecystectomy

Contaminated procedures 

  • GI / GU system with Non purulent inflammation  
  • Eg Same as above in an emergency setting

Dirty wounds 

  • Pus present , Peritonitis , Traumatic wound not managed for > 6 hrs

questions.text: The given image shows what grade of placenta previa?
questions.solution:
The given image shows grade III placenta previa.

  •  Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the
    lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents with delayed puberty. Investigations reveal increased levels of gonadotropins. Which among the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased levels of gonadotropins pointing towards Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and Klinefelter's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Klinefelter's syndrome is the most common sex chromosomal aneuploidy in males. Most of them have 47 XXY chromosomes. The diagnosis is rarely made before puberty, behavioral or psychiatric disorders may be apparent long before the defects in sexual development.

Causes of delayed puberty:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central):

Hypogonadism due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production

  • Malnutrition, systemic diseases
  • Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure):

Hypogonadism due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body)

  • Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Ovotesticular dysgenesis

Fractures can be complete or incomplete. 

Complete fractures: Most fractures occur due to a combination of forces, but the dominant mechanism of force is revealed by the type of fracture:

  • Tension causes transverse fracture or avulsion of a small fragment of bone at the points of ligament or tendon insertion
  • The compression causes an oblique fracture
  • Bending causes fracture with triangular ‘butterfly’ fragment
  • Twisting (torsion) causes a spiral fracture

If the fracture fragments are jammed together and the fracture line is not visible, it is known as an impacted fracture.

If the fracture has more than two fragments, it is known as a comminuted fracture.

Incomplete fractures

  • Greenstick fractures: Bending forces can result in incomplete or “greenstick” fractures in the pediatric population. The bone doesn't break completely. The outer cortex breaks and the inner cortex bends causing the bone to buckle like snapping of a green twig.
  • Compression fractures: Cancellous bone crumple due to force. This is typically seen in vertebral bodies, calcaneum and the tibial plateau.

questions.text: A pediatrician refers a child for psychiatric evaluation of pica as the child's mother complained of persistent eating of nonnutritive substances. According to DSM-5, what must be the minimum age attained by this child for the diagnosis of pica?
questions.solution:
A minimum of 2 years of age is suggested by DSM-5 for the diagnosis of pica.

Pica is defined as the persistent eating of nonnutritive substances.

Pica is more common among children and adolescents with autism spectrum disorder and intellectual disability.

The clinical implications can be benign or life-threatening, depending on the objects ingested. Among the most serious complications are lead poisoning (usually from lead-based paint), intestinal parasites after ingestion of soil or feces, anemia and zinc deficiency after ingestion of clay, and intestinal obstruction from the ingestion of hairballs, stones, or gravel.

No definitive treatment exists for pica. Most treatment is aimed at education and behavior modification. Medical complications (e.g., lead poisoning) that develop secondarily to the pica must also be treated.

questions.text: What is the oxygen delivery rate of the device shown below?
questions.solution:
The equipment shown in the image is a non-rebreather mask. It can give up to 10-15 litres of oxygen per minute.

The non-rebreather mask is a low-flow device that can be used to deliver oxygen at higher concentrations (FiO2 80-95%). It is used in patients who are severely hypoxic but are ventilating well. It uses a reservoir bag to let the oxygen get concentrated while a one-way valve doesn't allow it to breathe in expired air.

Other examples of low-flow devices are:

  • Nasal cannula
  • Face mask
  • Face tent

High-flow devices include:

  • Venturi mask
  • High-flow nasal cannula
  • Mechanical ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following health program management method is not based on quantitative methods?
questions.solution:
Management by objective is based on behavioral sciences. In this, objectives are set forth in different units and subunits, each of which prepares its own plan of action -usually on a short-term basis.

The other options are quantitative methods.

Quantitative methods are derived from the field of economics, operation research, and budgeting.

questions.text: A patient presents with oral cavity findings are seen in the image below. He is a smoker and has leukoplakia. What would you choose as your next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do biopsy

questions.solution:
The next step of management of this patient will be cessation of smoking and do a biopsy.

The patient is a chronic smoker and has leukoplakia. Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity.The management include elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion.

A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long term follow up.

questions.text: Not true regarding the test shown in the image is __________

choices.text: < 5 mm of moisture - severe Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
Fluorescein dye test is an alternative

questions.solution:
The image shows a Schirmer’s test being performed. It is measured after 5 minutes, not 10 minutes.

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: All of the following tests can be used to check the cessation of circulation, except:
questions.solution:
Winslow’s test is used to check the cessation of respiration while the Diaphanous test, Magnus’s test and Icard’s test are done to check the cessation of circulation.  

Winslow's test consists of placing a bowl of water on the chest and monitoring the movement on the water's surface.

Other tests for confirming cessation of breathing. are:

  • No audible breath sounds on continuous auscultation of the upper part of the chest and in front of or on the larynx for a minimum of 5 minutes
  • Feather test – No movement of a feather held in front of the nose
  • Mirror test – A mirror held in front of the nose does not turn dim due to any moisture in breath.

Tests for confirming cessation of circulation:

  • No audible heart sounds on continuous auscultation on the precordial area of the chest for a minimum of 5 minutes and a flat ECG recording for 5 minutes
  • Magnus’s test (Ligature test) - Fingers fail to show congestion distal to a ligature applied at their base
  • Diaphanous test (Transillumination test) - Failure to show redness in the webspace between the fingers on transillumination from behind
  • Icard’s test - Fluorescent dye on being injected at a given site in a dead body fails to produce any discoloration
  • Fingernail test - No blanching and filling of blood in the fingernail on the application of pressure and release

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with a 2 cm thyroid nodule. The histology of the tumour is given below. Most common mutation associated with this tumour is?
questions.solution:
The image shows the histology of papillary carcinoma thyroid as evidenced by the presence of orphan-Annie eye nuclei. BRAF mutation is the most common mutation in papillary thyroid cancer and is associated with lymph node metastases and a higher recurrence rate.

One third to one-half of papillary thyroid carcinomas harbour a gain-of-function mutation in the BRAF gene. The RET mutations are present in approximately 20% to 40% of papillary thyroid cancers.

Microscopic Features of Papillary carcinoma of  thyroid.

  • Complex, branching, randomly oriented papillae with fibrovascular cores associated with follicles.
  • Usually dense fibrosis.
  • Papillae lined by cuboidal cells.
  • Nuclei are overlapping with finely dispersed optically clear chromatin (also called ground-glass).
  • Orphan-Annie eye nuclei.
  • Macronucleoli, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions (represent cytoplasmic invaginations) and nuclear longitudinal grooves (represent folding of the redundant nuclear membrane, but nonspecific).
  • Stromal elastosis in 66% - often lymphatic invasion.
  • Psammoma bodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about vitamin B6?

choices.text: It is primarily stored in the liver
Serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions
It has no role in heme synthesis

questions.solution:
Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), an active form of pyridoxine(Vitamin B6) serves as a coenzyme in transamination reactions.

Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) is a coenzyme for enzymes involved in the following:

  • Transamination 
  • Decarboxylation
  • Glycogenolysis: Glycogen phosphorylase
  • Transsulfuration reaction: Cystathionine β-synthase and cystathionase
  • Heme synthesis: ALA synthase, (deficiency causes microcytic hypochromic anemia)
  • Tryptophan metabolism: Kynureninase, (deficiency causes pellagra like symptoms)

Other options:

Vitamin B6 is primarily stored in the muscle and is released during fasting.

It activates glycogen phosphorylase, an enzyme involved in glycogen breakdown.

It doesn't catalyze reactions of gluconeogenesis, but acts as a coenzyme for transamination reactions, giving rise to substrates of gluconeogenesis.

Note: Pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) serves as a coenzyme in many amino acid metabolisms, so its RDA mainly depends on daily protein intake.

questions.text: Persistent flexor spasm, profuse sweating, spontaneous defecation and urination, and hypertension following spinal trauma are components of:
questions.solution:
The phenomenon described is Mass reflex.

Mass reflex (also called autonomic dysreflexia/hyperreflexia), can occur following any Spinal Cord Injury (especially below T6 level), and an episode can be triggered essentially by any painful or irritating stimulus below the level of spinal cord injury. The most common stimulus being bladder distension (in 75-85% of cases). The effects of the reflex are as follows:

  • Major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into flexor spasm.
  • Colon and bladder evacuate
  • Arterial pressures rise to maximum values (SBP sometimes well over 200 mmHg
  • Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating.

Other Options:

  • Spinal shock: when the spinal cord is transected (commonly, above the level of T6 ), initially all cord functions including cord reflexes immediately become depressed to a point of total silence, often it is associated with arterial hypotension and bradycardia. After a few hours to weeks, the spinal neurons gradually regain their excitability. Since the above case has flexor spasm with hypertension and the level of lesion is below T6, it is not a spinal shock.
  • Cord righting reflex: When a spinal animal is laid on its side, it will make uncoordinated movements to try to raise itself to the standing position. This reflex is unrelated to the above case scenario.
  • Magnet reaction: The locus of the pressure on one side of the pad of foot causes extension in that direction, this effect is called the magnet reaction. This reaction helps keep an animal from falling to that side.
